problem: What is $3^{-1} + 13^{-1} \pmod{19}$? Express your answer as an integer from $0$ to $18$, inclusive.
solution: If we first get a "common denominator" as if 3 and 13 represent real numbers rather than residues, we get $$\frac 13 + \frac 1{13} \equiv \frac{13 + 3}{39} \equiv \frac{16}{2 \cdot 19 + 1} \equiv \frac {16}1 \equiv \boxed{16} \pmod{19}.$$We can justify this as follows: let $a \equiv 3^{-1} \pmod{19}$ and $b \equiv 13^{-1} \pmod{19}$. Then $39a \equiv 13 \pmod{19}$ and $39b \equiv 3 \pmod{19}$. Summing these congruences shows that $39(a+b) \equiv a+b \equiv 13 + 3 \equiv 16 \pmod{19}$, so $a+b \equiv 16 \pmod{19}$, as desired.
